content: The "Legal Reform Commission Act of 1998" is established by this Act. The Legal Reform Commission, established by the Legal Reform Commission Act of 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various government officials. The Legal Reform Commission, established by the Legal Reform Commission Act of 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various government officials. Two members are appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives. The Commission selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members. The Chairman cannot be a current or former federal government employee, and members cannot be current or former members of any State Bar. Appointments must be made by June 1, 1998, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Legal Reform Commission, established in 1998, consists of 11 members appointed by various officials. The Commission selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairman, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for decision-making. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on reforming and simplifying the US legal system, including Federal and State law, criminal and civil law, judicial processes, and rules of evidence and procedure. They are required to develop recommendations within 2 years of enactment. The Commission is mandated to study and reform the US legal system, including Federal and State law, within 2 years. They must submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. They are also responsible for personnel matters. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal government officers or employees. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Commission can appoint personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman can also procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. Sums necessary for the Commission's operations are authorized to be appropriated without fiscal year limitation.
